title: CTRL0000916066 - Transcribed Interview of Francis Connor, (July 7, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 1:05 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
JOHN GILSENAN, ASSISTANT FEDERAL PUBLIC DEFENDER
Why don't we go on the record at 1:05 p.m.
This is a transcribed interview of Mr. Francis Connor conducted by the House
Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol
And at this time I would ask the witness to please state your full name and spell
your last name for the record.
My last name is spelled C-O-N-N-0-R.
So this will be a staff-led interview, and at the time, I don't see any other staff
members beside myself, investigative counsel i!ii!H hill, on the Webex.
members join, they can ask questions as well, but none of them have joined the Webex
And at this time, could counsel please state your name for the record?
John Gilsenan, Assistant Federal Public Defender, on behalf
I would also like to note that we have staff members
- o n the Webex as well.
So as I mentioned, there is an official reporter transcribing the record of this
Please wait until each question is completed before you begin your response,
We will try to wait until your response is complete before we ask our next
speaking over each other, so it's really helpful that we make sure to wait until the other is
It's just very hard in these virtual settings for the stenographer to hear us
shaking your head, so it's important that you answer each question with an audible verbal
Also, the stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses such as
And we ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
If the question is not clear, just please ask for clarification.
If you do not know the
So I'm going to go over a couple of points to keep in mind as we're going along.
First, it's important that you understand that this interview is voluntary.
time you would like to stop speaking with us, that is your choice.
point you need to discuss something with your attorney in private, let us know, and we
will take a break so you can have that conversation.
Second, this interview is not under oath, but because this is a formal congressional
investigation, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth, the same as if you
were speaking with the FBI or the DOJ.
It is unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
interview, providing false information could result in criminal penalties for false
Third, you are not obligated to keep the facts of this interview and
us, including the prosecutor or judge on your case, or you can tell no one at all.
You are free to tell whomever you wish that you met with
Fourth, the select committee is separate and independent from the Department
We have no involvement with the prosecutions, and DOJ is not a partner
with the select committee in its investigation.
to your criminal case, and is not agreeing to submit anything on your behalf to the judge,
nor can we make any representation whether, if you tell the judge you met with us, that
the judge will be more favorable to you during sentencing.
And I would like to note for the record that Representative Stephanie Murphy has
The select committee also is not a party
Fifth, we have agreed with your attorney not to share the substance of what you
say with the Department of Justice prior to your sentencing, but there are two possible
was unaware of, or if we had reason to believe you lied during the interview, then we
would be obligated to tell the Department of Justice or another appropriate law
that may prompt questions from the judge about what you said, whether it is consistent
with your prior statements and acceptance of responsibility.
asking questions, we may get asked to respond and divulge what you said.
If you told us about evidence of a crime that we thought law enforcement
And if you tell the judge that you met with us, please understand
So just logistically, if you need any break for comfort, or if you would like to
discuss anything with Mr. Gilsenan, just let us know.
And remember, like it might happen if you don't understand a question or I'm not
clear, just ask me to repeat it.
I am happy to do so.
So with that, unless there are any questions, we'll get into the substantive part of
Currently I live in Staten Island.
And what is your educational background?
I have about a year of college completed.
Nothing I would call a career, just temporary jobs.
Mr. Connor, where do you live currently?
And how long have you lived there?
And what do you currently do for a living?
Have you had any other careers besides working at Amazon?
So, in general, how would you describe your level of political
I was up to date with the news.
What do you mean by that?
Were you following him on Facebook, Twitter?
Did you follow President Trump closely during his 4 years in office?
What sorts of information did you use?
Like where were you getting your information from?
I mean, I had him on social media, but everything I
know is from my own research.
Just things that I may Google or something like that.
what -- how I stayed up to date with what Donald Trump was saying, it was through Fox
News, maybe what was on his Twitter.
So you used Twitter or you used Google; you followed the
Were you paying attention to any sites like Reddit?
Did you ever visit anything known as TheDonald.win?
So what do you think you used the most, anything besides Fox News?
Did you have a Parler account?
Have you heard of a website called Gab, G-A-B?
So right after the general election in 2020, did you believe that
the election was stolen from former President Trump?
I believe that there was questions that needed to be asked.
And when did you start to form that belief?
Do you remember why you started to form that belief?
Because five States flipped at about 5:00 in the morning when I was
watching it on Eastern Coast Time after the polls were shut down.
So you stayed up all night watching the results?
Yeah, until like 4:30, and then I woke up and everything got flipped.
And before the election, the immediate time before, were you paying
attention to things President Trump was saying about the possibility of fraud in the
election on his Twitter account or something else?
Do you think that influenced your views about the election results at all?
Because there was -- they shut the polling down at, like, 2:00 in the morning.
So why were you concerned that the States had flipped?
Then Donald Trump came out and spoke, and then I saw the leads that he held in
Minnesota and Michigan, Pennsylvania, Georgia, and then the next morning everything
So I just thought it was very odd how it happened overnight.
Do you remember what President Trump said that night?
I believe he said something like, I've never seen anyone shut down the polls
like this, and in his own opinion, he won on the night of the election.
And did you believe him when he said that he won on the night of the
Well, I believe that -- I believe that's what he thought due to the fact that
they're closing down polls and things like that were happening, and it looked like he was
on the road to victory, so --
But you know votes were still being counted.
concerned about the fact that votes were still being counted?
Well, I just didn't understand why it would lead into, you know, weeks of
counting and all the audits and things like that.
So did you come to believe that the election was stolen at all after the 2020
I believe that there was fishy things that happened and questions that
But I'm asking specifically, did you believe that the 2020 election
was stolen from former President Trump?
I'm saying that things that happened that were on, you know, video
surveillance that happened were not along the lines of how an election should go in the
country, so I believe that those questions are needed to be asked.
President Trump did ask those questions.
And have you heard about any investigations into answering those
I heard about audits in, like, certain States and whatnot.
And did any of those audits, or whatever, assuage your concerns
about what had happened in the 2020 election?
Because I feel like the news was just trying to basically label Donald Trump
as being crazy for asking certain questions that needed to be asked and the news was just
It wasn't a full-fledged effort of looking into what happened.
But was the news media looking into it or were government entities looking
Due to what the news reported, I don't -- I don't -- I'm -- I really don't know.
I don't know what to think of what they said.
So let's go back to how you were feeling in the immediate aftermath
In your statement of offense, there's some lnstagram messages between yourself
Am I pronouncing his last name correctly?
I'm sorry, I didn't hear you.
I think you cut out for a second.
First, how do you know Mr. Ferrigno and Mr. Lunyk?
And is it correct that you went to January 6th with those two
So in these lnstagram messages, these are from your statement of offense,
I'm just going to read a couple of them.
So on November 3rd you said, "Get after it."
"Don't let the Democratic Party destroy our country," end quote.
On November 5th, quote, "Hopefully Civil War comes," close quote.
It's going to be a fight, but we got this."
November 9th you say, quote, "Be ready for Civil War to erupt because the
liberals are going to riot," close quote.
On November 10th, Mr. Lunyk said, "We're going to be at the epicenter of the Civil
So those are a number of messages in which it sounds like war and fighting are the
Why did you use that language?
It's my private conversations with my friends.
And I've already gone over this with everybody, so -Well, I understand you've already answered these questions before, Mr.
Connor, but we're not privy to your questioning and answering with the FBI, DOJ all the
I've just -- I've gone over my private messages with everybody, and it's
well-known that there was no intent behind those messages.
And I don't know who everybody is, and I have not heard or listened
to those conversations, so just treat me as someone without any of that background
I'm just asking you, so why did you use that language?
I don't want any war, no Civil -- or any Civil War, anything like that.
just me talking with my friends.
Because it was a private conversation.
Why were you talking about Civil War?
me and my friends joking around.
Do you think Civil War is funny?
So how is it a joke?
It's just -- no intent behind it.
Because it's just private conversations with my friends.
I understand that, but it sounds like the topic here was about the election,
and you're talking about war around the election and specifically use, it seems,
Democrats were trying to destroy the country.
you're saying you're joking, I want to know why you're picking those specific words?
So I'm asking what prompted you to use
Whether you're thinking of it as a private conversation, whether
think it's a joke that those things could happen in this country, so -- do you think it's a
And, I mean, I had my own
I mean, things that needed to be investigated, things like that, I don't
Well, now I'm a little confused because you said these were jokes.
I said it in a joking manner.
I don't believe that there should be people
killing each other in the streets, but what I do believe is that there was needed further
investigation into the election, so -All right.
Francis, I think what-is trying to get at it is, how are you
feeling, what emotion was behind those messages?
I felt betrayed by our government.
BYCan you expand on that a little bit more?
I was just disappointed, and I felt betrayed in our government just due to the
fact that there's a way things, you know, should work in the country, and things seemed
one-sided and it was unfair to, you know, more than half the country.
So does that mean you did believe the election was stolen?
I believe that there was fraud in the election.
Enough fraud to tip the balance for President Trump?
Most likely if the correct investigation was done.
So besides these text messages -- sorry -- lnstagram messages after
the election, did you participate in any, like, activities related to alleged voter fraud?
did you go out and collect affidavits for the Trump campaigns, litigation, or do anything
And did you between -- actually, just after the election until now, did
you make any donations to President Trump or other political entities --
And did you attend the November 14th rally in Washington, D.C.?
I appreciate that you wanted to, and you are free to do what you want --
Can you tell me why you went to that?
I have an appreciation for Washington, D.C.,
and I just think it's a nice place, and I wanted to go there with my friends.
I believe it was like a weekend, so we decided to go down there just to see, you
So you wanted to go to Washington, D.C., to attend the rally,
But it wasn't a Donald Trump rally.
But you could have done that another day.
That's the day the rally was.
Trump had nothing to -- Donald Trump had nothing to do with that rally.
Do you remember the phrase "Stop the Steal"?
Was it -- would you consider it a Stop the Steal rally?
I didn't support -- it wasn't like a Donald Trump
So what does the phrase "Stop the Steal" mean to you in the context
It means stop the stealing of the election.
So do you believe that that message was to support President Trump?
So was that rally, in a sense, a rally for President Trump then?
It was for Donald Trump, of course, but it wasn't, like, the
January 6th thing that was formulated by Donald Trump.
Donald Trump rally where you have to go through security checks on January 6th, and
things like that, and Secret Service, and whatever other people were there, before you
It was just a bunch of citizens met up in -- I
forgot what the park was called.
So, yeah, I mean, of course, it was for Donald Trump.
It was right near the White House, and that was it.
We went to the -- I'm forgetting the name of what the park was called, but
What did you do that day?
we went to the park at, like, 6:00 in the morning.
bunch of Trump supporters from around the United States there.
conversations with, you know, people from different States and whatnot.
they set up the stage, there was a few people who spoke.
was nobody like an important -- you know, that held government positions that really
listened to what they had to say.
It was just, you know, known Trump supporters from social media, and we just
And then after that, they walked down to the Supreme Court, and there was just a
bunch of people on the megaphone, you know, saying to look into the election results,
Do you remember if they asked U.S. citizens to do anything to further the
So what was the hope and goal of the rally?
Let me speak to my lawyer.
I was just wondering what the hope for the rally was.
I feel like they just wanted to -- they invited -- Donald Trump's fan base got
together and wanted to show their representation in Washington, D.C., which turned out
to be a lot of people who came from all parts of the country, and they just wanted to
show, I guess, how many people felt a certain way about the election results.
And I would just like to note investigative counsel
has joined, and I think you can see him on screen right now.
And did you attend the November 14th rally with Mr. Ferrigno and Mr.
After the November 14th rally, were you continuing to pay attention to Stop
the Steal social media accounts, Stop the Steal social media messaging?
They were just on my -- like, my social media feed.
the 14th, after November 14th, that rally, I kind of just stayed in tune with the news and
what was going on in, like, early December with, like, audits and stuff like that.
follow -- I didn't donate to anything.
I wasn't out in, you know, the streets on my free
I was just in tune with the news.
And do you remember hearing about court cases that President Trump was
Do you remember hearing that he was losing a lot of those cases?
Well, how did that -- what did you think about those cases being thrown
I remember hearing a lot of them were just being, like, thrown out.
I think that with a topic as sensitive as the presidential election instead of,
you know, looking into these cases with a very minimal, you know, effort, it should have
And I don't think the highest effort was put into these court
Highest effort by the judges, highest effort by
I just think that whatever level of government, whatever the process is, it
should have been taken as serious as possible, and I don't believe it was.
And just what makes you think that it wasn't, the fact that they're dismissed
No, just the fact that they were just dismissed upon, you know,
But -- so when did you find out about the January 6th rally?
Did you also attend the December 12th rally --
Maybe the day before because Donald Trump posted it.
Donald Trump posted it on his
Are you talking about the December 19th tweet where it says, "Will be
Said there will be a wild protest.
He tweeted that on December 19th about the January 6th.
I think I was just aware that that was the day they were going to certify
the election results, and the decision was made to go there literally like the night before.
Maybe you can help clarify something because I pulled from your statement
of offense that on December 12th Mr. Lunyk sent a message in lnstagram to, I believe,
yourself and others that, by the way, electoral college final vote is on January 6th.
And then statement of offense says that you guys were talking about going to
Washington, D.C., for the next, like, 4 weeks or so.
I mean, I'm -- I was very in tune with the news.
knew that there was going to be something on January 6th.
I didn't know that I was
I had no part of the planning or anything like that.
So you knew about the certification, but you're saying that you didn't learn
about the rally itself until a couple of days before January 6th?
I don't remember when I learned about it.
I mean, this feels like forever
ago now, to be honest with you.
I don't know if it was December 28th, January 2nd.
You know, I don't really see it being, like, relevant, that answer, to be honest.
Just as best you can, do you remember a message from Mr. Trump about the
Well, it's up for us to decide what questions are relevant to ask, Mr. Connor.
I don't remember about the rally, messages, no.
Could I have a moment with Mr. Connor?
How do we do that, John?
I think he --1 mean, the best way we've handled this in the past is
that he'll sign out and come back in, and you can have the conversation, unless you have
another way to communicate with him.
And Mr. Connor can log off, take the phone call, and then we'll let
No, because it's his cell phone.
him back in the room, and then we'll go back on the record.
And I would like to note for the record that Representative Peter Aguilar has
We'll go back on the record.
And I believe before we went on recess, Mr. Connor, I was asking if you
remembered how you found out about the rally on the Ellipse on January 6th.
Do you have any sense of what it said?
It was just like a 3-D picture of the Ellipse, something like that, and said, Join
I only remember Donald Trump's last lnstagram post.
the January 6th rally starting at the Ellipse, something like that.
Do you think that was early January?
I believe it was, like, the day before, maybe January 4th.
So just to step in -- s o r r y , - - President Trump tweeted on January
5th, "See you in D.C." with a picture.
the day before that led to your decision to come to D.C.?
It's -- yeah, it's like a campaign picture, but I remember seeing it on
And was it around, like, the middle of the day on January 5th or
Do you remember the time of day?
So was Mr. Lunyk talking about going to Washington, D.C. at all in the month
Is this the tweet that you're referencing that was
And do you remember what made you want to go to Washington,
I figured it was going to be -- I never really attended -- I went to the
November rally, but it wasn't like a Donald Trump rally.
to see him speak before he left office, you know, like at an actual rally, so I decided, you
know, this is probably going to be, like, the last time he's, you know, President, and I'm
able to go to a rally like this so why don't I go.
So you didn't think he would stay in office past January 20th?
All the events that happened in November and December, like the things
we're talking about with the audits and whatnot, I just -- I didn't think -- I thought that
they were trying to, like, you know, fight to maybe have something be done about it, like
in terms of, like, the election results, but I didn't think that it was going to go the way I
watch him speak in person, and that's it.
But you did understand that Congress was certifying the electoral college
So I figured, you know, like, let me just go see him one last time and
But I didn't think it was going to go the way I wanted it to go and
everybody else wanted it to go.
Did you take the rally, though, to be a protest of that certification?
Did you believe that the purpose of the President's rally and the
purpose of the whole event on January 6th was to protest the certification of the vote for
I figured the rally was more of just him calling on his supporters, you know,
to be together and maybe have him speak in front of everyone one last time.
don't know what he expected out of it.
spoke before him, like Rudy Giuliani, Trump's family.
and see him in person, and that's about it.
I know that I wasn't -- I didn't go to Washington,
I went there to listen to Donald Trump speak and all the other people
I just wanted to hear him speak
I was just going to say, if President Trump wouldn't have done that tweet or
lnstagram or called you to come to Washington, D.C., would you have come on
There would have been no reason for me to go.
if there was no Trump rally -- because it was, like, I looked at that day as two separate
would have had no reason -- there was -- going down to Washington, D.C., on January 6th
wouldn't have even been a thought in my head.
So I guess, then, you were paying attention to the news, as you said, before
Do you remember what President Trump was talking about?
question, it's -- like I just want to
Yeah, basically I'm not the one to go and protest something.
I went for the Trump rally at the Ellipse.
I had no reason -- if there was no, like, actual Donald Trump campaign rally, I
So, you know, I just went there to listen to Donald Trump talk one last time, and
A n d _ I didn't hear the question that you asked.
I guess you were there to listen to President Trump speak, but President Trump
had been talking a lot about the election being stolen in the time leading up to January 6.
So was that a topic of conversation you were hoping to hear him speak about?
I just wanted to hear directly -- since I figured that it was, like, you know, his
last, like, legitimate -- like the Republican's last chance at maybe overturning or looking
into something, I wanted to just hear, you know, directly from him what he had to say.
mean, obviously, the whole topic of it was, oh, stolen election.
you know, what was really going on for myself, and I wanted to hear Donald Trump talk.
And he had Rudy Giuliani there with him, who was, like, his lawyer, and Rudy Giuliani was
trying his best to, like, do things like that or look into it.
listen to Donald Trump speak one last time.
I just wanted to be there and
So whatever he could have spoken about, I
I wasn't paying attention for any specific topic.
So why don't we just go to the day then.
Trump said, do you remember him talking about marching to the Capitol on January 6th?
I remember him saying, We're going to go over there peacefully and hope
for Mike Pence to decertify the results of the election.
And I believe that there was a
stage, and there was, like, a set-up thing on the other side of the building, and that's
where, like, things were supposed to be before they got too hectic.
Is that the reason you marched to the Capitol, though, President Trump's
Why did you march to the Capitol?
I was actually going home, and at this point -- because I was outside since
we -- once we got to the parking garage where the car that we were in was parked, I seen
on, like, Twitter and I had some people, like, call me, like saying, Look at the news, like,
look what's happening at the Capitol and whatnot.
So just out of -- we were there, and I was just -- it's -- I just wanted to see what
Like that's why I was there.
And so we walked over, and that was it.
It was cold that day, and we wanted to go home.
So did you stay for all of President Trump's speech at the Ellipse?
We left -- to, like, beat the crowd, we left about, I would say, like, 5 to, like,
10 minutes before he was done talking.
And then when we got into -- then we parked
far away, so the walk to the car was far away, and then we were in the car for, like -- for a
And you recall hearing President Trump mention the Capitol during his speech.
And when you say "we," who were you in the car with or who were
And your testimony just now is that that's not why you went to the
Yeah, I wasn't going because -- as I said, like, I understand people have,
like, political opinions and their intellect, this whole protesting thing, but I -- I don't feel
like me being there, it's not going to change anything, so I'm not into that stuff.
not why I went to the Capitol.
Did you hear anybody else in the crowd next to you that was talking about
going to the Capitol after President Trump said it?
I didn't go there to, like, protest or because Donald
You know, I make my own decisions.
Did you hear anyone in the crowd talking about Vice President Pence after
President Trump mentioned his name during the speech?
And how did you take it once President Trump said that he wanted Vice
President Pence to decertify the election, in so many words?
I thought that it was -- I thought it would have been a fair decision.
By Vice President Pence to do that?
And why would it have been fair?
Because there was more than half the country believed that there was some
So in terms of the American people, I think it would have been fair to the
Did you understand the consequences of Vice President Pence not certifying
I believe it would have led to like a State-by-State audit or, you know, an
extended period of just figuring out what was going on.
I'm just wondering what you had hoped for, that you said it was fair.
sounds like you would have hoped for more investigations, correct?
And do you think those would have -- there would have been enough time to
complete those before the January 20th inauguration?
I believe that, if I'm not mistaken, like, the process would have been
Well, I want to back up a little bit.
saying, This is history in the making.
But Mr. Lunyk on January 5th, sent another lnstagram message
Were you talking to Mr. Lunyk at all about the importance of January 6th before
It was just more of the -- it was more of the fact if we believed
that -- you know, if Pence overturned the election results or decertified it, then it would
It's just saying what it was, what it could have been.
And I know you said you went there just to hear President Trump
speak, but was it your understanding that other people went there in the hopes that the
speech, the rally, protest, whatever, would lead Vice President Pence to not certify the
I felt like, regardless of how many people went or what was said, Mike
Pence was going to make a decision based off of whatever he wanted to do.
So, in your view, then, all the people showing up were just there to listen to
President Trump and not to do anything else?
I can't -- I don't know why they were there.
I'm asking for your view of what other people were doing.
you to read their minds, just to be clear.
I know why I was there.
I can't speak for anyone else.
So what time did you get to Washington, D.C.?
the 5th, or did you get there on the 6th?
We might have left on the 6th, too, at, like,
12:00 a.m., like -- you know, we got there very early, like 4:00 or 5:00 in the morning, I
think, we arrived there, something like that.
And this is -- you drove with Mr. Ferrigno and Mr. Lunyk, correct?
So the morning of the 6th, Mr. Ferrigno said in an lnstagram
message, not to you, but to someone else, saying, Let's see what happens.
end up being an all-out Civil War.
So during the car ride down to Washington, D.C., or at all during that day, was Mr.
Ferrigno talking to you at all about the idea of Civil War?
We just listened to music the whole ride there.
So you guys didn't have any conversations about what would be
happening that day on your ride down?
And I know you said earlier that messages about Civil War were a joke
between you guys, but it seems to be repeating itself.
did you guys talk about the possibility of Civil War on January 6th?
time out into the future, like, what's going to happen.
We didn't -- we didn't go there thinking that anything violent was
We just -- it was -- when we say Civil War, it's talking about from that
the other half what could happen.
So I just want to ask straight up,
It's literally if half the country disagrees with
We're not saying that we're pushing for Civil War.
I guess the question is, war inherently is violent, right?
preparing for future debates with half the country, or future disagreements with half the
expecting when you used that term, I think is the question.
He used the term "Civil War," which was literally a war.
We're not sitting here, you know,
saying we want war, we want other Americans to die, like, these are just conversations
Well, did you think January 6th would lead to more disagreement at the very
If the results were decertified, then, sure.
So isn't that the outcome you wanted?
Yeah, but I didn't go there hoping -- thinking that was going to happen.
course, I'm a supporter of Donald Trump.
Donald Trump, but I didn't believe -- with all of the events from the day of the election to,
let's just say January 1st, the audits that were happening in November and December, I
didn't believe that it was actually going to happen.
I didn't think it was actually going to happen.
Obviously, I want the best outcome for
Of course, I wanted it to happen, but
But you said that, you know, the possibility of January 6th
leading to more disagreements could happen if Pence decertified the vote, and it sounds
like that's what you wanted to happen.
and if you knew that would lead to more disagreement, it sounds like you were willing, or
So if you wanted the decertification of the vote
Am I just misinterpreting what you're --
I'm willing -- if the election results were decertified, and I'm not
concerned with how, you know, the Democratic Party feels.
things should work for the country.
I'm thinking of what's best and how
I'm not sitting here trying to start a civil war or want
Like, if that's what you're trying to ask me, it's not -- you know, you're trying
to, like, find an answer, it's just not -- it's not making any sense.
Of course, I want the best situation for Donald
